awd_titl_txt: A New Approach to Capacitive Sensing: Repulsive Sensors
awd_abstract_narration:
Proposal Title: A New Approach to Capacitive Sensing: Repulsive Sensors

Brief Description of Project Goals: This research aims to devise a new approach to capacitive sensing and to demonstrate its effectiveness in MEMS microphones.

Abstract:

Nontechnical 
Hearing aids are useful tools an aging population can use to improve their quality of life. Miniature microphones are a key component in hearing aids and their acoustic performance determines the effectiveness of hearing aids in helping the hearing impaired communicate in noisy environments. Micro-Electro-Mechanical Systems (MEMS) microphones have grown to dominate the market for miniature microphones in portable electronic devices such as cell phones due to their small form factor as well as their compatibility with high-volume manufacturing processes. While MEMS microphones have the potential of providing significant performance improvements in hearing aids, they have generally not yet demonstrated sufficient performance for this demanding application. A goal of the proposed research is to take better advantage of MEMS technology to enable a revolutionary change in the design of high-performance MEMS microphones. If successful, this research will lead to more sensitive MEMS microphones for hearing aids and will have a tremendous impact on the lives of hearing impaired. Noise performance of the MEMS microphone will be the major improvement that can help the aging population hear better.

Technical 
Capacitive sensing using electrostatic repulsive fingers is a novel concept that can transform many applications suffering from limited functionality due to the pull-in instability of conventional parallel plate sensors. Since the invention of capacitive microphones in 1916, the limitation of pull-in voltage has significantly diminished the functionality of these devices in terms of noise performance and sensitivity. We propose using a Micro-Electro-Mechanical Systems (MEMS) capacitive sensing mechanism based on the repulsive force that, unlike conventional capacitive sensors, does not suffer from pull-in voltage. This approach allows significantly increased bias voltages that will substantially improve the signal-to-noise ratio and electrical sensitivity of microphones. The MEMS microphone examined here is composed of a silicon diaphragm that rotates about an axis upon exposure to sound pressure. The diaphragm incorporates a number of capacitive sensor unit cells, and their change in capacitance converts to a voltage in the preamplifier. A unit sensor cell consists of a movable finger above a vertically aligned fixed finger next to an unaligned fixed finger. When potential differences are made in the aligned and unaligned fingers, an asymmetric electric field is created on the movable finger, generating a repulsive force that pushes it away from the substrate. Our preliminary studies show that the initial gap of the unit sensor cell can be designed so the force on the movable finger remains repulsive, which prevents the collapse of the movable fingers on the substrate (pull-in). The asymmetric electric field distribution on the movable finger causes a complicated coupled relationship between the capacitance and mechanical displacement. Therefore, to gain a fundamental understanding of the coupled system behavior, we will create analytical and numerical models of the capacitive MEMS sensor. Using the model simulations, we will design the sensor for desired sensitivity. Using microfabrication techniques, we will build the sensor and characterize its behavior using a Laser Doppler Vibrometer. After integrating the sensor with preamplifier circuitry, we will test the system in an anechoic chamber to verify the sensor improves the performance and sensitivity of microphones.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: The major goal of this research was to create new capacitive sensors called "repulsive sensors" that avoid the undesired "pull-in" instability. Almost all capacitive sensors are based on two charged electrodes and they are hampered by pull-in instability because of nonlinear electrostatic forces.  Eliminating pull-in instability enables a sensor to have a large stroke and a high bias voltage, both of which increase the electrical sensitivity and resolution. Our repulsive mechanism consists of four electrodes where the two middle ones are often grounded and the two on the side are subjected to voltage excitations. Our research delineated the underlying physical phenomenon of electrostatic levitation (repulsive force) based on four electrode arrangements that prevented the pull-in instability. We provided a comprehensive understanding of the resultant complicated electrostatic forces. We thoroughly investigated the static and dynamic behavior of different mechanical structures subjected to electrostatic levitation and studied the nonlinear dynamic characteristics in depth. We have also merged electrostatic levitation with conventional parallel plate electrode systems and achieved a linear actuator system that can have a large stroke and tunable frequency that varies linearly with voltage. This unique property is very advantageous to MEMS oscillators, filters and sensors. The mathematical model that we created was used as a platform to discover numerous high-performance devices that employ repulsive sensors. We validated the theoretical models using experimental techniques and showed the predictions are in close agreements. We made prototypes of Micro-electro-mechanical systems (MEMS) microphones and accelerometers based on this revolutionary sensing mechanism and showed the sensitivity of these devices can be improved by increasing the bias voltage that often causes failure in conventional devices. We went well beyond the promises of the proposal to show the capability of repulsive sensors to improve MEMS microphones and innovated MEMS filters and pressure sensors that showed greater functionality and resolution. The results of this project were published in 14 top-tier journals including Journal of Applied Physics, IEEE Sensors Journal, IEEE Transactions on Industrial Electronics, and 7 international conference proceedings.  

 

Broader Impact: The repulsive sensors discovered as part of this proposal is revolutionary to billions of electronic devices made every day. We demonstrated numerous creative devices that can benefit from this new sensing concept including MEMS accelerometers, microphones, pressure sensors and filters. The efforts made in this project resulted in a patent disclosure titled "Electrodynamically Levitated Actuator" that innovatively combines repulsive sensors with triboelectric generators for creation of self-powered shock sensors. These shock sensors are completely passive and autonomous that respond to shocks beyond certain limits. The deep understanding and mathematical platform that we developed for repulsive sensors can open up doors to physical sensors that are not hampered by pull-in failure and can achieve unprecedented signal-to-noise ratio and accuracy. As part of this project, three undergraduate students and three graduate students were trained and graduated. The three undergraduate students trained as part of the REU program are currently studying at the graduate level and working in the industry. One of the graduate students received a one-year internship as part of NSF INTERN program working at Xallent, a startup company in Ithaca, NY. The intern program exposed the student to a whole new working eco-system in comparison to the academic workplace. He experienced how to conduct collaborative teamwork in a fast-paced startup environment.  These new and improved sets of skills eventually made him a highly competent candidate in the job market, among others. In fact, he was hired by the same company after graduation. One graduate student found a proper research and development position at Seagate Technologies and the other student became a postdoctoral fellow after graduation working on a NIH hearing aid project. During the four-year project, investigators participated in engineer?s week community day and held workshops showing sensing concepts to students of k-12 such as simple microphones, electromagnetic shakers, dancing balls and moving cans. These simple yet effective workshops sparked interest in young minds to pursue engineering in the future.
